course.subject: CORE
course.name: Environmental Science
course.description: The course introduces students without a science background to the general concepts of environment, natural resources, and sustainable development. Topics include pressing global, regional and local environmental issues; renewable and non-renewable energy; life-supporting systems of our planet and its biodiversity; atmosphere, air pollution and global climate change; water resources and pollution; ocean plastics and solid waste management; environmental health and toxicology. Throughout the course, students will gain a sufficient background and a better understanding of the root causes of key environmental issues. They will also become more aware of their role, as individuals, in environmental protection and sustainable development.
course.prerequisites: a passing letter grade in CORE 1401 OR CORE 1402 OR CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1002 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: LIFS 1030, OCES 1010

reviews.author: vva
reviews.comment_content: The content taught is very mixed. Teach a little bit of everything. Including biology, geography, physical chemistry and other knowledge. The overall course is an introductory letter. There are many new words.
reviews.comment_teaching: The class over all about reading powerpoint. I don't listen much to lessons myself. But the teacher will add some content that is not in the ppt in class. And because the students were obviously not listening, the teacher was a little upset about this. There have been cases where quizzes have been used as an excuse for students to come to class.
reviews.comment_grading: Me: A. The course won't be challenging unless you are not willing to recite the ppt content. You still need to prepare for the in-class quiz. Although it's an open-book test,  you won't have enough time to search for the answer unless you are familiar enough for the contents.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The first half of the course was taught by Dr. Lam and the second half was taught by Dr. Yau.
Both Dr. Lam and Dr. Yau taught well. They explained the concepts clearly during the class. There were some extra slides and information that were mentioned in class only, and would be apperared in the exams. Make sure you pay attention in the class and jot notes.

If you want to get an A grade in this course, make sure you don't skip any classes and stay focus in the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm examination: 45% (MCQs)
Final examination: 45% (MCQs)
In-class IPRS quizes: 10% (MCQs)

There were 4 IPRS quizes during the whole semester.

Midterm: median: 37/50 (highest: 48/50)
Final: median: 43/60 (highest: 59/60)
IPRS quizes: most get 9-10/10 in each quiz

Me:
Midterm: 42/50
Final: 56/60
IPRS quizes: one 6/10; two 9/10; one 10/10

Final grade: A

Midterms and final exams are close book, close notes while IPRS quizes are open book and open Internet. You can search the information on notes and Internet.

Some questions were quite tricky and you  had to think twice before submitting the final answer. Also, it is a good time for you to learn from the mistakes that you  made in the IPRS quizes.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite small for this course. Just one midterm exam, one final exam and four IPRS quizes.
